channel.title: Nature Communications - current - nature.com science feeds
channel.description: Nature Communications is an online-only, multidisciplinary journal dedicated to publishing high-quality research in all areas of the biological, physical and chemical sciences. Papers published by the journal represent important advances of significance to specialists within each field.

item.title: Layer number dependent ferroelasticity in 2D Ruddlesden–Popper organic-inorganic hybrid perovskites
item.content:encoded:
Nature Communications, Published online: 26 February 2021; doi:10.1038/s41467-021-21493-w

Ruddlesden popper layered perovskites can be used in optoelectronic devices, but the understanding of their lattice strain as well as ferroelasticity is still lacking. Here, the authors find ferroelasticity in layered perovskites with layer number more than one and reveal its mechanism.
item.dc:title: Layer number dependent ferroelasticity in 2D Ruddlesden–Popper organic-inorganic hybrid perovskites
item.dc:creator: Xun Xiao
Jian Zhou
Kepeng Song
Jingjing Zhao
Yu Zhou
Peter Neil Rudd
Yu Han
Ju Li
Jinsong Huang

item.title: A family of ionic supersalts with covalent-like directionality and unconventional multiferroicity
item.content:encoded:
Nature Communications, Published online: 26 February 2021; doi:10.1038/s41467-021-21597-3

Binary ionic crystals, such as NaCl, are non-polar due to directionless ionic bonding interactions. Here, the authors show that polarity can be developed by using superalkali/superhalogen ions as building blocks, leading to ionic supersalts with ferroelectricity, ferroelasticity or even triferroicity.
item.dc:title: A family of ionic supersalts with covalent-like directionality and unconventional multiferroicity
item.dc:creator: Yaxin Gao
Menghao Wu
Puru Jena

item.title: Ultracold atom interferometry in space
item.content:encoded:
Nature Communications, Published online: 26 February 2021; doi:10.1038/s41467-021-21628-z

Conducting atom-optical experiments in space is interesting for fundamental physics and challenging due to different environment compared to ground. Here the authors report matter-wave interferometry in space using atomic BECs in a sounding rocket.
item.dc:title: Ultracold atom interferometry in space
item.dc:creator: Maike D. Lachmann

item.title: Catalytic asymmetric reductive hydroalkylation of enamides and enecarbamates to chiral aliphatic amines
item.content:encoded:
Nature Communications, Published online: 26 February 2021; doi:10.1038/s41467-021-21600-x

Enantiopure aliphatic amines are frequently encountered as chiral auxiliaries and synthetic intermediates for bioactive compounds. Here, the authors report a mild nickel-catalysed asymmetric reductive hydroalkylation to convert enamides and enecarbamates into α-branched chiral amines and derivatives.
item.dc:title: Catalytic asymmetric reductive hydroalkylation of enamides and enecarbamates to chiral aliphatic amines
item.dc:creator: Jia-Wang Wang
Yan Li
Wan Nie
Zhe Chang
Zi-An Yu
Yi-Fan Zhao
Xi Lu
Yao Fu

item.title: Melting of subducted sediments reconciles geophysical images of subduction zones
item.content:encoded:
Nature Communications, Published online: 26 February 2021; doi:10.1038/s41467-021-21657-8

Here, the authors identify that magnetotelluric conductive anomalies commonly observed on the trenchward-side of volcanic arcs in subduction zones can be explained by subducted sediments. High-pressure experiments show that these sediment melts will react with the overlying mantle wedge to produce electrically conductive phlogopite pyroxenites.
item.dc:title: Melting of subducted sediments reconciles geophysical images of subduction zones
item.dc:creator: M. W. Förster
K. Selway

item.title: Ultrarobust, tough and highly stretchable self-healing materials based on cartilage-inspired noncovalent assembly nanostructure
item.content:encoded:
Nature Communications, Published online: 26 February 2021; doi:10.1038/s41467-021-21577-7

Strong self-healing materials with high healing efficiency are of great use in many fields but their fabrication is extremely challenging. Here, the authors present a robust self-healing material by incorporating high density noncovalent bonds at the interfaces between dentritic tannic acid-modified tungsten disulfide nanosheets and a polyurethane matrix to collectively produce a strong interfacial interaction.
item.dc:title: Ultrarobust, tough and highly stretchable self-healing materials based on cartilage-inspired noncovalent assembly nanostructure
item.dc:creator: Yuyan Wang
Xin Huang
Xinxing Zhang

item.title: Combinatorial CRISPR screen identifies fitness effects of gene paralogues
item.content:encoded:
Nature Communications, Published online: 26 February 2021; doi:10.1038/s41467-021-21478-9

Systematic screens for synthetic lethal gene pairs represent a powerful approach to define interactions that may be exploited in the clinic. Here, the authors use a dual-guide CRISPR screening approach to screen a curated selection of gene pairs across three cell lines and validate the Fam50a/Fam50b synthetic lethality was in isogenic cell models as well as in an in vivo setting.
item.dc:title: Combinatorial CRISPR screen identifies fitness effects of gene paralogues
item.dc:creator: Nicola A. Thompson

item.title: Retroviral integrations contribute to elevated host cancer rates during germline invasion
item.content:encoded:
Nature Communications, Published online: 26 February 2021; doi:10.1038/s41467-021-21612-7

Koalas are susceptible to neoplasms, which are related to infection with the Koala retrovirus. Here, the authors use DNA sequencing to show that the retroviral insertion sites cluster near known cancer genes and demonstrate a high mutational load associated with the germline invasion of the virus.
item.dc:title: Retroviral integrations contribute to elevated host cancer rates during germline invasion
item.dc:creator: Gayle K. McEwen
David E. Alquezar-Planas
